results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains footage of a visit to the Gresswell Sanatorium in Mont Park, Victoria, which at the time housed and treated male patients with tuberculosis. Mont Park was an area north-east of Melbourne comprising several health institutions, including the Gresswell Sanatorium which was named after Dan Gresswell, a public health administrator. The film provides an insightful look at life in the sanatorium, including recreational activities and health care.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 great example of a handpainted sign reading ‘Repatriation Sanatorium, Drive Slow, Gresswell Sanatorium’
00:00:13:00 a 1940s style bus with logo ‘Heidelberg Motor Omnibus Service Pty. Ltd.’
00:00:40:00 a woman in 1940s style dress disembarks the bus
00:01:22:00 three men walking down the road
00:01:58:00 a man using a grinding wheel in a work shed
00:03:11:00 meal time at the sanatorium
00:04:07:00 a cheeky group of people in conversation, with several poking their tongue out to the camera
00:06:18:00 playing cricket with branches amongst the trees
00:07:22:00 a patient being treated with an injection and valve, presumably to relieve air from the lung, a common treatment for tuberculosis at the time
00:08:56:00 nurse in uniform of the era with a long veil

results.title: [Ted Parsons Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
Ted Parsons was a keen amateur filmmaker of the 1940s to 1960s. Ted’s films feature life in and around the Victorian regional city of Wangaratta post-war. This was a period of prosperity and optimism largely due to a successful textile industry that took Wangaratta from a small country town to major rural city, declared in 1959.

Ted captures the many sporting and social events, venues and clubs, holidays and travel along with scenes of everyday life. The collection also shows the broader issues faced by country people such as the regular flooding events around the Ovens and King Rivers.

Wangaratta’s success story as a manufacturing town traces the path of post-war migration and the accompanying growth of Australia’s economy, which makes these films particularly interesting.

The Ted Parsons Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s grandson Barry Parsons. The films have been made on 16mm film.

The majority of this film is comprised of scenes from the Athletic Carnival, showing a great snapshot of sport and fashions of the period.

It also features scenes from the Cheshunt State School in the King Valley, showing the schoolchildren learning about river erosion. This section of film was possibly filmed as part of a documentary made by members of the Wangaratta Camera Club called ‘Treasures of the King’, which was made to show the need for a dam across the King River.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a parade with a marching band
00:01:00:00 Union Jack flying
00:02:00:00 bagpipes and highland dancing
00:02:52:00 Cheshunt State School, a small weatherboard building
00:02:59:00 schoolchildren sitting on the grass
00:03:10:00 a teacher in cat eye glasses speaking to the children in front of the school
00:03:29:00 two men with cameras taking photographs of the children in their lesson
00:04:02:00 the children making a dam, learning about river erosion
00:04:51:00 title card ‘Wangaratta Athletic Carnival 1958’
00:06:37:00 sprinters set off
00:07:06:00 man with a starter pistol
00:08:09:00 woman in a pink polka dot dress wearing a hat made out of newspaper
00:08:31:00 boy in a tartan cap eating a Peters brand ice cream
00:08:46:00 sign ‘W.B. Richardson Stand’
00:10:23:00 truck sprinkles the track with water from a tank; a handwritten sign on the tank reads ‘No training while watering’
00:10:36:00 a man shows off to the camera, flipping a cigarette into his mouth while smoking
00:11:58:00 firemen demonstration; the teams have the name of their town emblazoned on their shirts, including Myrtleford, Bright and Wangaratta
00:13:56:00 a stylish couple, both dressed in white, the woman wearing a ruffled lace halterneck

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film contains three distinct scenes. The first is footage of an arts and crafts show, including jewellery, pottery and sculpture on display; the second is a man weaving a basket; and the third shows children and adolescents in a gymnastics class, practising somersaults, cartwheels and back flips.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 displays of jewellery and pottery
00:00:55:00 a girl in white cat eye glasses
00:01:51:00 a man basket weaving
00:02:28:00 a group of children and adolescents practising somersaults in a gymnastics class
00:04:05:00 cartwheels and back flips

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughte. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia, with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures a roadtrip to South Australia showing several ports and towns and the landscapes and ocean views along the way.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 title card ‘Exploring South Australia’ using a Shell (Gas and Oil) roadmap of SA
00:00:22:00 the Balmera Post Office with signs reading ‘Post and Telegraph Office’ and ‘Money Order and Commonwealth Savings Bank’
00:00:31:00 a town street with a large truck loaded with full hessian sacks followed by views of roses in the median strip gardens
00:01:32:00 Mrs Rankine holds some very large grapefruit
00:02:10:00 the travellers enjoy some public gardens
00:02:00:00 a ‘To Adelaide’ road sign on a flooded road, alongside some boats
00:03:20:00 filming from a punt that takes the travellers and cars across a waterway
00:05:00:00 sign reading ‘Port Augusta: Change here for Quorn Alice Springs’ followed by views of the rail station
00:05:20:00 street scenes with pedestrians, cars and buses
00:05:35:00 a long pipeline travels alongside a road in which Mrs Rankine, in a wonderful navy blue suit, sunglasses and cream ‘Maryjane’ style shoes, stands by the car taking in the views followed by two travellers on a motorcycle (motorbike)
00:06:13:00 the Whyalla Post Office followed by quiet street scenes including motorists and motorbike riders, an Orlando Wines advertising sign, lovely older buildings such as the Hotel Spencer and a great example of a 1940s or 1950s style small truck parked outside.
00:06:45:00 Mrs Rankine stands on a balcony of the hotel
00:06:57:00 a steam train carrying what appears to be aggregate crushed rock for road construction comes into view and shortly after, workers release the load into trackside rock and gravel piles, a fisherman and his bike on the pier and the rock being loaded onto the ship by way of a conveyor belt system
00:08:58:00 Mrs Rankine sits atop a very large pipeline, fanning flies away from her face
00:09:28:00 lengthy views of industrial works and cargo loading facilities
00:11:51:00 a lone blue-tongue lizard
00:12:18:00 the family car sits on top of a rise overlooking grassland and the sea, a ship, a town and in the foreground, an unusually low electricity pole and wiring
00:13:05:00 a ‘Port Lincoln’ sign on a building followed by scenes of the town, the bays, bobbing boats, public flowerbeds and 1940s and 1950s style cars, trucks and houses
00:14:53:00 the Pier Hotel with Mrs Rankine on a balcony and then in a window knitting with the blue and green sea in the background
00:15:15:00 scenes around the foreshore, out over the water, yachts, small boats and jettys and grassy shorelines
00:16:20:00 Mrs Rankine on shore in the blustery winds
00:16:55:00 a rail crossing on a sandy road with a ‘Commonwealth Roads’ sign warning of a ‘£50 penalty’
00:17:27:00 a wonderful ageing and long pier with a lighthouse at the end
00:17:42:00 a building bearing the name Port Pirie followed by views of the town and port, including a tugboat pulling a large ship into dock
00:18:15:00 another ship, named Pioneer Reef New York
00:18:18:00 a closer view of one of the tugboats followed by the Rankine family car parked on a dusty road
00:18:40:00 four big draught horses pulling a plough and then seven pulling a cultivator

results.description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughte. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia, with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures a roadtrip to South Australia showing several ports and towns and the landscapes and ocean views along the way.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This short film shows scenes of the Royal Botanic Gardens and the Sydney Harbour Bridge in New South Wales.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:25:00 the Sydney Harbour Bridge in the background
00:01:13:00 Sydney city streets

results.title: [Taronga Park; Sydney Harbour Bridge; The Great Barrier Reef; Peeping at Perth]
results.creator_credit: Eric Merton, Kodak Cinegraph and Perier Films
results.brief_description:
This film contains four short tourism films edited together, possibly by Ted Parsons.

The first film shows Taronga Zoological Park in Sydney, New South Wales, which was opened to the public in 1916 as a popular tourist destination. The segment shows various species of animals, in particular Australian marsupials (including kangaroos and koalas) and reptiles (including a goanna and a green python). The animals are introduced with title cards.

The second section of film shows the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney beaches. The film shows the arched bridge, including views from the top of it, as well as surfing at Bondi, coastal views of Palm Beach and surf lifesaving at Manly.

The third segment shows close-ups of rockpools by the Great Barrier Reef, including crustaceans, sea snails and starfish. It also shows wildlife, including birds and turtles, along the beaches in Queensland.

In the fourth section, the highlights of Perth, Western Australia are shown. The film shows views across the Perth city, King’s Park, the buildings in London Court and the grand buildings of the University of Western Australia.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this short film, we see scenes of Melbourne, Victoria, including landmark buildings such as Flinders Street Station and St Patrick’s Cathedral. Of particular note are the wide clear streets and the 1950s style cars.

This film was made on Standard 8mm film.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film Kenneth and some fellow travellers visit the Grampians showing the varied scenery across the mountainous ranges and the valley, groups of people relaxing and enjoying natural surrounds as well as hiking and gathering for a picnic.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:07:00 title card ‘Our Grampians’ starts us off travelling along a country road where we see the sign to Halls Gap and other local towns, followed by a sign for “Hotel Bellfield” and a spot of golf.

00:00:02:00 ‘Splitter Falls’ sign appears ahead of more views of the mountainous range, roads and the valley below.
00:04:12:00 a very long waterfall.

00:04:57:00 a group of tourist overlooling the hills from a high vantage point.

00:05:13:00 a photographer setting up a spectacular looking shot of people sitting on rocks.

00:06:37:00 toasting bread on an open fire and the sign ‘New scenic track to McKenzie Falls’.

00:09:27:00 women holding a bunch of wildflowers one of whom sports a classic 40’s headscarf style.

00:10:21:00 we see a tree being prepared for felling by two mean using a double ended saw followed by a logging truck.

00:11:14:00 sign to ‘Wonderland’ followed by a large group of people trekking up a rocky incline, taking rests on the rocks, climbing narrow ravines and finally looking out from the top.

00:15:07:00 the travellers stand around a fire with a billy-can, cooking lambchops and bread.

00:17:12:00 a farmer and his tractor from a close view and pink tinged clouds.

description_for_label:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film Kenneth and some fellow travellers visit the Grampians showing the varied scenery across the mountainous ranges and the valley, groups of people relaxing and enjoying natural surrounds as well as hiking and gathering for a picnic.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:07:00 title card ‘Our Grampians’ starts us off travelling along a country road where we see the sign to Halls Gap and other local towns, followed by a sign for “Hotel Bellfield” and a spot of golf.

00:00:02:00 ‘Splitter Falls’ sign appears ahead of more views of the mountainous range, roads and the valley below.
00:04:12:00 a very long waterfall.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, we see a trip to Beechworth in 1969 for the ‘Gemboree’, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. The first ‘Gemboree’ was held in 1965 as a gathering of lapidaries to showcase gemstones and minerals and has continued annually since. The film opens with elaborate title cards setting up the film, which is credited to both Tibor and wife Merna Koller. The film contains footage of country Victoria and the festival, including great shots of cars, caravans and tents of the era. It also shows interesting footage of gemstones on display.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Combined Lapidary Clubs of Victoria presents’, ‘1969 Gemboree Beechworth’
00:00:27:00 ‘Script & Narration: John Royle’
00:00:59:00 ‘Compiled & Filmed by TZ & MM Koller’
00:01:05:00 a man exits a wooden shed in the bush
00:01:48:00 panning for gold in the river
00:02:31:00 signpost ‘Woolshed Falls’
00:03:05:00 children panning for gold
00:04:11:00 sausages cooking on a hot plate
00:04:30:00 ‘Welcome to Beechworth’ road sign, followed by views around the town
00:06:14:00 cars driving down the main street
00:06:24:00 a yellow banner stretched across the road reads ‘Dulux Paints Welcomes You to Gemboree ‘69, National Lapidary Festival’
00:07:44:00 handmade signs for various lapidary clubs and some great examples of caravans and cars of the era
00:09:14:00 crowds of people at the festival
00:12:21:00 1950s style cars
00:13:01:00 a large group of people in the bush prospecting
00:14:09:00 toddler in a play pen
00:14:56:00 a man grinding a gemstone on a grinding wheel
00:15:39:00 ‘Exhibition Entries This Way’ followed by prize winners of the Gemboree on display
00:18:32:00 gemstones on display in cabinets
00:20:18:00 a bonfire
